pros: Good pay, I was on £7.25 at age 18.  All staff spoke fluent English and were very friendly and caring. Training was very thorough. Very peaceful working environment.
cons: Not enough initial information was given about the residents to me the carer when I first started the job. I didn't get to read any care files and this made it a very slow and difficult process to get to know residents and deliver quality one to one care based around residents preferences. After suffering bad mental health problems deputy manager constructively dismissed me. Rather than recieving help such  as fewer hours management failed to tell me thay the company had a free confidential counselling service. Rather than offering support, sick leave or making compromises the staff said I should quit. I also wasn't given a uniform for quite a few days and was never given a name badge like the other staff which undoubtedly made it hard on the residents as they had dementia.

review_title: Everybody's heart is in the right place and doing the right thing
pros:
Nearly every person who I have met here is definitely doing their role with the sole purpose of doing the best they can to impact our customers and employees positively.

This company has lots of passionate, dedicated employees who genuinely care about delivering great standards, whether they are in a office support function, a direct care role, IT or somewhere in senior management.

Direct care roles / outside of support centre have lots of opportunities to develop their skills or abilities, either through qualifications or progression within their teams. There have been lots of examples of people who began in an entry level role who have then progressed to Managerial positions and further.

Generally the company has a good reputation as an employer, so I can be proud to say that I work for Somerset Care.

The Senior Management Team and most of my direct managers recognise hard work and dedication and will let me know that I have done a good job or I have made a difference.

I believe that the company is under good direction and the future will be good. There are lots of improvements being made / have recently been made which already have made a huge impact on efficiency, quality and staff happiness. (Positively!)
cons:
As a large care company working ultimately within the restrictions that local Health and Social Care funding place upon them, pay rates and the benefits package for some roles are comparatively low/undesirable to the same role in other sectors.

There has been some culture of 'it's always been done this way' and hesitance to adapt to and embrace new ideas or processes - however this has begun to change in the last 12 months.

Within my role and team in The Support Centre there is little to no opportunity to progress formally, and development in the form of qualifications is not offered. Within the scope of my work I have capacity to develop my skills by practicing and speaking with my direct line manager but there is no formal pathway or development plan.

There has been some previous culture of 'them and us' which in my personal experience has mainly come from teams working outside of the Support Centre, and it has been difficult to overcome this, despite our need to work together in order to be effective. Again, this is improving all the time.
